item.title: Example Page 1

item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic's Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: Writing technical content in Academic
item.description:
Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.

Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.

On this page, you'll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.

Examples

Code

Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.toml file.

```python
import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()
```

renders as

import pandas as pd
data = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
data.head()

Math

Academic supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.toml file.

To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with $...$ or $$...$$, respectively.

Example math block:

$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ 
\left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T 
\left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}
{\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$

renders as

$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left |\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right |^2}$$

Example inline math $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$ renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.

Example multi-line math using the \\ math linebreak:

$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \\
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$

renders as

$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$

Diagrams

Academic supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.

An example flowchart:

```mermaid
graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]
```

renders as

graph TD
A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round)
B --> C{Decision}
C -->|One| D[Result 1]
C -->|Two| E[Result 2]

An example sequence diagram:

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
loop Healthcheck
    John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
end
Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
John-->>Alice: Great!
John->>Bob: How about you?
Bob-->>John: Jolly good!
```

renders as

sequenceDiagram
Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
loop Healthcheck
    John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
end
Note right of John: Rational thoughts!
John-->>Alice: Great!
John->>Bob: How about you?
Bob-->>John: Jolly good!

An example Gantt diagram:

```mermaid
gantt
section Section
Completed :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active        :active,  des2, 2014-01-07, 3d
Parallel 1   :         des3, after des1, 1d
Parallel 2   :         des4, after des1, 1d
Parallel 3   :         des5, after des3, 1d
Parallel 4   :         des6, after des4, 1d
```

renders as

gantt
section Section
Completed :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active        :active,  des2, 2014-01-07, 3d
Parallel 1   :         des3, after des1, 1d
Parallel 2   :         des4, after des1, 1d
Parallel 3   :         des5, after des3, 1d
Parallel 4   :         des6, after des4, 1d

An example class diagram:

```mermaid
classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
<<interface>> Class01
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
class Class10 {
  <<service>>
  int id
  size()
}
```

renders as

classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
<<interface>> Class01
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
class Class10 {
  <<service>>
  int id
  size()
}

An example state diagram:

```mermaid
stateDiagram
[*] --> Still
Still --> [*]
Still --> Moving
Moving --> Still
Moving --> Crash
Crash --> [*]
```

renders as

stateDiagram
[*] --> Still
Still --> [*]
Still --> Moving
Moving --> Still
Moving --> Crash
Crash --> [*]

Todo lists

You can even write your todo lists in Academic too:

- [x] Write math example
- [x] Write diagram example
- [ ] Do something else

renders as

  • Write math example
  • Write diagram example
  • Do something else

Tables

Represent your data in tables:

| First Header  | Second Header |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |
| Content Cell  | Content Cell  |

renders as

First Header Second Header
Content Cell Content Cell
Content Cell Content Cell

Asides

Academic supports a shortcode for asides, also referred to as notices, hints, or alerts. By wrapping a paragraph in {{% alert note %}} ... {{% /alert %}}, it will render as an aside.

{{% alert note %}}
A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.
{{% /alert %}}

renders as

A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.

Did you find this page helpful? Consider sharing it üôå

item.title: An example preprint / working paper
item.description:
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic's Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.

item.title: Display Jupyter Notebooks with Academic
item.description:
from IPython.core.display import Image
Image('https://www.python.org/static/community_logos/python-logo-master-v3-TM-flattened.png')


print("Welcome to Academic!")

Welcome to Academic!

Install Python and JupyterLab

Install Anaconda which includes Python 3 and JupyterLab.

Alternatively, install JupyterLab with pip3 install jupyterlab.

Create or upload a Jupyter notebook

Run the following commands in your Terminal, substituting <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER> and <SHORT-POST-TITLE> with the file path to your Academic website folder and a short title for your blog post (use hyphens instead of spaces), respectively:

mkdir -p <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/
cd <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/
jupyter lab index.ipynb

The jupyter command above will launch the JupyterLab editor, allowing us to add Academic metadata and write the content.

Edit your post metadata

The first cell of your Jupter notebook will contain your post metadata (front matter).

In Jupter, choose Markdown as the type of the first cell and wrap your Academic metadata in three dashes, indicating that it is YAML front matter:

---
title: My post's title
date: 2019-09-01

# Put any other Academic metadata here...
---

Edit the metadata of your post, using the documentation as a guide to the available options.

To set a featured image, place an image named featured into your post's folder.

For other tips, such as using math, see the guide on writing content with Academic.

Convert notebook to Markdown

jupyter nbconvert index.ipynb --to markdown --NbConvertApp.output_files_dir=.

Example

This post was created with Jupyter. The orginal files can be found at https://github.com/gcushen/hugo-academic/tree/master/exampleSite/content/post/jupyter

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/img/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let's make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation

item.title: Internal Project
item.description:
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Duis posuere tellus ac convallis placerat. Proin tincidunt magna sed ex sollicitudin condimentum. item.title: Academic: the website builder for Hugo
item.description:
Create a free website with Academic using Markdown, Jupyter, or RStudio. Choose a beautiful color theme and build anything with the Page Builder - over 40 widgets, themes, and language packs included!

Check out the latest demo of what you'll get in less than 10 minutes, or view the showcase of personal, project, and business sites.

  • üëâ Get Started
  • üìö View the documentation
  • üí¨ Ask a question on the forum
  • üë• Chat with the community
  • üê¶ Twitter: @source_themes @GeorgeCushen #MadeWithAcademic
  • üí° Request a feature or report a bug
  • ‚¨ÜÔ∏è Updating? View the Update Guide and Release Notes
  • ‚ù§ Support development of Academic:
    • ‚òïÔ∏è Donate a coffee
    • üíµ Become a backer on Patreon
    • üñºÔ∏è Decorate your laptop or journal with an Academic sticker
    • üëï Wear the T-shirt
    • üë©‚Äçüíª Contribute

Key features:

  • Page builder - Create anything with widgets and elements
  • Edit any type of content - Blog posts, publications, talks, slides, projects, and more!
  • Create content in Markdown, Jupyter, or RStudio
  • Plugin System - Fully customizable color and font themes
  • Display Code and Math - Code highlighting and LaTeX math supported
  • Integrations - Google Analytics, Disqus commenting, Maps, Contact Forms, and more!
  • Beautiful Site - Simple and refreshing one page design
  • Industry-Leading SEO - Help get your website found on search engines and social media
  • Media Galleries - Display your images and videos with captions in a customizable gallery
  • Mobile Friendly - Look amazing on every screen with a mobile friendly version of your site
  • Multi-language - 15+ language packs including English, ‰∏≠Êñá, and Portugu√™s
  • Multi-user - Each author gets their own profile page
  • Privacy Pack - Assists with GDPR
  • Stand Out - Bring your site to life with animation, parallax backgrounds, and scroll effects
  • One-Click Deployment - No servers. No databases. Only files.

Themes

Academic comes with automatic day (light) and night (dark) mode built-in. Alternatively, visitors can choose their preferred mode - click the sun/moon icon in the top right of the Demo to see it in action! Day/night mode can also be disabled by the site admin in params.toml.

Choose a stunning theme and font for your site. Themes are fully customizable.

Ecosystem

  • Academic Admin: An admin tool to import publications from BibTeX or import assets for an offline site
  • Academic Scripts: Scripts to help migrate content to new versions of Academic

Install

You can choose from one of the following four methods to install:

  • one-click install using your web browser (recommended)
  • install on your computer using Git with the Command Prompt/Terminal app
  • install on your computer by downloading the ZIP files
  • install on your computer with RStudio

Then personalize and deploy your new site.

Updating

View the Update Guide.

Feel free to star the project on Github to help keep track of updates.

License

Copyright 2016-present George Cushen.

Released under the MIT license.

item.title: An example journal article
item.description:
Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic's Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description:
R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)
##      speed           dist       
##  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
##  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
##  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
##  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
##  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
##  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
fit
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)        speed  
##     -17.579        3.932

Including Plots

You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:

par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
pie(
  c(280, 60, 20),
  c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'),
  col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'),
  init.angle = -50, border = NA
)

Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.

Click the Slides button above to demo Academic's Markdown slides feature.

item.title: project_one
item.description:
Introduction

Snowshoe hares, Lepus americanus, can be found in boreal and upper montane forests across North America. Snowshoe hares are primarily herbivorous, eating a variety of flowers, grasses, and plants. In Alaska, hares depend more heavily on grasses and leaves in the summer months, and twigs and bark during the winter. This project aims to explore the seasonal weight distributions of snowhoe hare populations living throughout the Tanana valley in Alaska (Department of Fish and Game).

knitr::include_graphics('/images/picture.jpg')

Snowshoe hares have adapted to blend in with their surroundings by seasonally changing their coat colors.

Credit: Denali National Park and Preserve

Data and Methods

Data for snowshoe hare weights, measured in grams, from 1999-2012 collected and provided by Bonanza Creek LTER research team. Hare measurements obtained from capture-recapture studies across 5 locations in the Tanana valley. For more information on data collection procedures, and the project as a whole, see metadata. Data from September, October, and November have been grouped together under ‚Äúfall‚Äù, March, April, and May have been grouped under ‚Äúspring‚Äù, and June, July, and August have been grouped under ‚ÄúSummer‚Äù. We did not compare data from the winter months due to a deficit in data collected during this time. Additionally, observations without clear age or gender measurements were removed. All figures were prepared using R software version 3.6.1.

!

knitr::include_graphics('/images/map.jpg')

Snowshoe hare capture-recapture studies occured along the Tanana River and throughout the Bonanza Experimental Research Forest.

Credit: Long Term Ecological Research Network

# attach packages and read in data
library(tidyverse)
library(purrr)
library(dplyr)
library(lubridate)
library(tidyr)
library(car)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(effsize)
library(kableExtra)
library(janitor)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(broom)
hare <- read_csv(("showshoe_lter.csv"), na= "0")

Results

# select data I'm interested in working with (adult males) and drop na values
hare_am <- hare %>% 
  select(date, weight, age, sex) %>% 
  drop_na() %>% 
  filter(age == "a"| age == "A") %>% 
  filter(sex == "m"| sex == "M")
# specify dates just by month
hare_month <- hare_am %>% 
  mutate(date_new = lubridate::mdy(date)) %>% 
  mutate(month = lubridate::month(date_new, label = TRUE)) %>% 
  select(weight, month) 
# sort data by seasons
hare_seasons<- hare_month %>% 
  mutate(season = dplyr::case_when(month %in% c("Jan", "Feb", "Dec") ~ "winter",
                   month %in% c("Sep", "Oct", "Nov") ~ "fall",
                   month  %in% c("Jun", "Jul", "Aug") ~ "summer",
                   month  %in% c("Mar", "Apr", "May") ~ "spring")) %>% 
  select(weight, season)
# calculate summary statistics
hare_summary <- hare_seasons %>% 
  group_by(season) %>% 
  summarize(mean_weight = round(mean(weight),1),
            median= round(median(weight),1),
            sd_weight = round(sd(weight),1),
            sample_n = n(),
            se_weight = round(sd(weight, na.rm = TRUE) / sqrt(n()),1),
            var_weight = var(weight, na.rm = TRUE))
# make graph visualizing adult male snowshoe hare weights by season and customize
ggplot()+
geom_beeswarm (data = hare_seasons, aes(x = season, y = weight), size = 1, alpha = .5,pch = 16, color = "#4D6483")+
scale_x_discrete (labels = c("Fall", "Spring", "Summer", "Winter"))+
labs(x = "Season", y = " Weight (Grams)", title = "Snowshoe Hare Weights by Season \n Adult Males (1999-2012)")+
geom_point(data = hare_summary, aes(x=season, y= mean_weight), color = "maroon", size = 2.5)+
geom_point(data = hare_summary, aes(x=season, y= median), color = "blue", size = 1.5, alpha = .7)+
geom_errorbar(data = hare_summary, 
                aes(x = season, 
                    ymin = mean_weight - sd_weight,
                    ymax = mean_weight + sd_weight),
                color = "#612F62",
                width = 0.09) +
  theme_light()+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust= 0.5,
                                  face = "bold",
                                  size = 16,
                                  margin=margin(0,0,10,0)))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(10,0,0,0))) +
  theme(axis.title.y = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(0,10,0,0)))+
  scale_y_continuous(limits=c(0,2250), breaks = seq(0,2250, by=250), expand = c(0,0))+
  theme(panel.background = element_rect(colour = "black", size=1))+
  theme(panel.grid.minor = element_blank())

Figure 1: Seasonal weight differences, excluding Winter, in adult male Snowshoe hares (1999-2012). Gray points indicate individual hare weights, measured in grams. Maroon points indicate sample means, and error bars indicate ¬± standard deviation. Median sample weights are indicated by smaller blue points. Data Source: Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present

Table 1: Adult male snowshoe hare size metrics

# make table of summary statistics (grouped by season)
hare_table <-hare_summary %>% 
  select(-se_weight) %>% 
  select(-var_weight)

  hare_table %>% 
    kable(col.names = c("Season", 
                      "Mean Weight (grams)",
                      "Median Weight (grams)",
                      "Standard Deviation",
                      "Sample Size")) %>% 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "bordered", 
                full_width = F,
                position = "left") %>% 
  row_spec(1, background = "#C3C7CC") %>% 
  row_spec(3, background = "#C3C7CC") %>% 
  row_spec(2, background = "#F1F2F3")
Season Mean Weight (grams) Median Weight (grams) Standard Deviation Sample Size
fall 1588.4 1620 134.9 92
spring 1492.6 1500 110.4 55
summer 1372.4 1350 213.5 151

The average mean and median weights of adult male snowshoe hares differ seasonally. Data collected during the fall, spring, and summer months illustrate that on average, adult male hares are the heaviest in fall and weigh the least throughout summer (Figure 1). These trends hold true for both mean and median weight measurements. On average, adult male hares weigh 95.8 grams more in the fall than in the spring, and 216 grams more in the fall than in the summer based on mean measurements. Median weights differ by 120 grams between fall and spring, and 270 grams between fall and summer (Table 1).

References

Alaska Department of Fish and Game ‚ÄúSnowshoe Hare Species Profile, Alaska Department of Fish and Game.‚Äù Snowshoe Hare (Lepus Americanus), www.adfg.alaska.gov/index.cfm?adfg=snowshoehare.main.

Kielland K., F. S. Chapin, R. W. Ruess. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14.

item.title: project_three
item.description:
Introduction

This project explores Steelhead fish use of the Bonneville Dam. Steelhead Trout are a migratory fish species, often migrating between the ocean and freshwater sources many times throughout their life. Steelhead trout are born in freshwater and migrate to the ocean before reaching adulthood. Later in life, these fish will migrate up the same river in which they were born to spawn (FWS). Human disturbances to the natural ecosystem, including the creation and modification of dams, are one of the many threats to Steelhead populations (Center for Biological Diversity). The Bonneville dam, located between Oregon and Washington, is complete with a 70 foot fish ladder which allows for the safe passage of fish through the dam (Northwest Power and Conservation Council). This project explores the daily, monthly, and annual counts of Steelhead Trout observed passing through the Bonneville dam from 1939-2019. Data provided by Columbia River Research.

knitr::include_graphics('/images/Rainbow_trout.png')

Credit: Duane Raver

Results

# Attach libraries and read in data
library(tidyverse)
## ‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse 1.2.1 ‚îÄ‚îÄ
## ‚úì ggplot2 3.2.1     ‚úì purrr   0.3.3
## ‚úì tibble  2.1.3     ‚úì dplyr   0.8.4
## ‚úì tidyr   1.0.0     ‚úì stringr 1.4.0
## ‚úì readr   1.3.1     ‚úì forcats 0.4.0
## ‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ
## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
## x dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
library(tsibble)
## 
## Attaching package: 'tsibble'
## The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr':
## 
##     id
library(fable)
## Loading required package: fabletools
library(fabletools)
library(feasts)
library(forecast)
## Registered S3 method overwritten by 'quantmod':
##   method            from
##   as.zoo.data.frame zoo
## Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'forecast':
##   method             from    
##   fitted.fracdiff    fracdiff
##   residuals.fracdiff fracdiff
## 
## Attaching package: 'forecast'
## The following objects are masked from 'package:fabletools':
## 
##     GeomForecast, StatForecast
library(janitor)
## 
## Attaching package: 'janitor'
## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
## 
##     chisq.test, fisher.test
steelhead <- read_csv("cbr_fish_passage_bonneville_allyrs_steelhead.csv")
## Parsed with column specification:
## cols(
##   year = col_double(),
##   `mm-dd` = col_character(),
##   location = col_character(),
##   parameter = col_character(),
##   unit = col_character(),
##   datatype = col_character(),
##   value = col_double()
## )
# wrangle to get dates in various formats
steelhead_date <- steelhead %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  separate(mm_dd, into = c("day","month_abb"), sep = "-") %>% 
  mutate (month = match(month_abb,month.abb)) 

steelhead_date$new_date <-lubridate::ymd(paste(steelhead_date$year, steelhead_date$month, steelhead_date$day, sep="-")) 
## Warning: 61 failed to parse.
steelhead_date_2 <- steelhead_date %>%
  drop_na(new_date, value) %>% 
  mutate(month_sep = yearmonth(new_date)) %>% 
  mutate(value = as.numeric(value)) %>% 
  drop_na(month_sep, value) %>% 
  mutate(month_new = lubridate::month(new_date, label = TRUE))

# view(steelhead_date_2)

steelhead_mmdd <- steelhead %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  rename(month_date = mm_dd)

steelhead_final <- steelhead_date_2 %>% 
  select(location:value,new_date:month_new) %>% 
  mutate(year = lubridate::year(new_date))
# ONE: Time series of original observations (daily)
ggplot(data = steelhead_final, aes(x = new_date, y = value)) +
  geom_line(color = "blue")+
  theme_minimal()+
  labs(x = "Date", y = "Daily Fish Counts", title = "Daily Steelhead Passage \n Through the Bonneville Dam (1939-2019)") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust= 0.5,
                                  face = "bold",
                                  size = 16,
                                  margin=margin(0,0,10,0)))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(10,0,0,0))) +
  theme(axis.title.y = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(0,10,0,0)))

Figure 1: Daily Steelhead Trout counts at the Bonneville Dam. Daily observations obtains from January 1st, 1939 through December 31st, 2019. Data: Columbia River Research.

Large daily variations in Steelhead Trout counts exist at the Bonneville Dam between 1939-2019. The highest daily recorded fish count was 34,053 fish in one day, while no fish were observed on other days.

# TWO: Time series of seasonplot (monthly)
steelhead_monthly <- steelhead_final %>% 
  group_by(month_new, year) %>% 
  summarize(month_sum = sum(value))

ggplot(steelhead_monthly, aes(x = month_new, y = month_sum, group = year)) +
  geom_line(aes(color = year)) +
  labs(x = "Month", y = "Monthly Fish Counts", title ="Total Monthly Steelhead Passage \n Through the Bonneville Dam (by Year)")+
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma)+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust= 0.5,
                                  face = "bold",
                                  size = 16,
                                  margin=margin(0,0,10,0)))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(10,0,0,0))) +
  theme(axis.title.y = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(0,10,0,0)))+
  scale_color_gradient(low='#66D367', high='#4371CC')

Figure 2: Monthly Steelhead Trout counts at the Bonneville Dam. Fish counts obtained daily and totaled together to obtain monthly counts. Earlier observations represented by green lines, while later years are in blue. Data: Columbia River Research

Observations of Steelhead Trout populations at the Bonneville dam appear to follow similar monthly trends across the years. While very few fish are observed between January-May and October-November, fish counts have drastically increased during June-September months during all recorded years. It appears that monthly fish counts are greatest in August, possibly suggesting yearly migration patterns.

# THREE: Time series of annual steelhead counts


steelhead_annual <- steelhead_final %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  summarize(annual_sum = sum(value))

# using tsibble:
# annual_ts <- as_tsibble(steelhead_annual, index = year)
# annual_ts %>% autoplot(annual_sum) # I'll graph in ggplot instead
# annual_ts %>% gg_subseries(annual_sum) # does not work
# annual_ts %>% gg_season(annual_sum) # does not work

ggplot(data = steelhead_annual, aes(x = year, y = annual_sum)) +
  geom_line(color = "maroon") +
  theme_minimal()+
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Annual Fish Counts", title = "Total Annual Steelhead Passage \n Through the Bonneville Dam")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust= 0.5,
                                  face = "bold",
                                  size = 16,
                                  margin=margin(0,0,10,0)))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(10,0,0,0))) +
  theme(axis.title.y = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(0,10,0,0)))+
  scale_color_gradient(low='#6CE98E', high='#5072DF')+
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma)

Figure 3: Annual Steelhead Trout counts at the Bonneville Dam. Yearly totals obtained from 1939-2019. Data: Columbia River Research

It appears that while there are significant yearly fluctuations in Steelhead Trout populations traveling through the Bonneville dam, annual Steelhead Trout counts are generally increasing over time. Most notable, very large increases in Steelhead Trout populations were observed in 2001 and 2009. These dramatic increases were rapidly followed by a decline in fish by the following year.

References

Columbia River DART, Columbia Basin Research, University of Washington. (2019). Adult Passage Graphics & Text. Available from http://www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_graph_text

‚ÄúDams: Impacts on Salmon and Steelhead.‚Äù Northwest Power and Conservation Council, www.nwcouncil.org/reports/columbia-river-history/damsimpacts.

‚ÄúNatural History: CENTRAL CALIFORNIA COAST STEELHEAD TROUT.‚Äù Center for Biological Diversity, www.biologicaldiversity.org/species/fish/central_California_coast_steelhead_trout/natural_history.html.

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service/Fish and Aquatic Conservation. ‚ÄúSteelhead Trout.‚Äù Official Web Page of the U S Fish and Wildlife Service, www.fws.gov/fisheries/fishmigration/steelhead_trout.html.

item.title: project_two
item.description:
knitr::include_graphics('/images/fastfood.jpg')

Credit: freepik

Introduction

This report explores the relationship between nutrients present in sampled fast foods. The nutritional content of 371 common fast food items were analyzed, using 11 common nutritional measures for comparison. This report will explore which nutrients, if any, were positively and negatively correlated to one another. Data for this project provided USDA (National Nutrient Database), now FoodData Central

# read in data and attach packages
library(tidyverse)
## ‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse 1.2.1 ‚îÄ‚îÄ
## ‚úì ggplot2 3.2.1     ‚úì purrr   0.3.3
## ‚úì tibble  2.1.3     ‚úì dplyr   0.8.4
## ‚úì tidyr   1.0.0     ‚úì stringr 1.4.0
## ‚úì readr   1.3.1     ‚úì forcats 0.4.0
## ‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ
## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
## x dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
library(janitor)
## 
## Attaching package: 'janitor'
## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
## 
##     chisq.test, fisher.test
library(ggfortify)

food <- read_csv("usda_nutrients.csv") %>% 
  clean_names() 
## Parsed with column specification:
## cols(
##   .default = col_double(),
##   FoodGroup = col_character(),
##   ShortDescrip = col_character(),
##   Descrip = col_character(),
##   CommonName = col_character(),
##   MfgName = col_character(),
##   ScientificName = col_character()
## )
## See spec(...) for full column specifications.
#Select data of interest, drop na values, rename columes
food_filtered <- food %>% 
  filter(food_group == "Fast Foods") %>% 
  select(protein_g: fiber_g, energy_kcal, vit_a_mcg:vit_e_mg) %>% 
  drop_na() %>% 
  rename(Energy = energy_kcal) %>% 
  rename(Protein = protein_g) %>% 
  rename(Fat = fat_g) %>% 
  rename(Carbohydrates = carb_g) %>% 
  rename(Sugar = sugar_g) %>% 
  rename(Fiber = fiber_g) %>% 
  rename(VitA = vit_a_mcg) %>% 
  rename(VitB6 = vit_b6_mg) %>% 
  rename(VitB12 = vit_b12_mcg) %>% 
  rename(VitC = vit_c_mg) %>% 
  rename(VitE = vit_e_mg)  
# Run principal component analysis on selected variables
food_pca <- prcomp(food_filtered, scale = TRUE)
#summary(food_pca)

#plot(food_pca)
#biplot(food_pca)
# Create a biplot of results and add customizations
food_biplot <- autoplot(food_pca, 
                      colour = NA,
                      loadings.label = TRUE,
                      loadings.label.size = 3,
                      loadings.label.colour = "black",
                      loadings.colour='maroon',
                      loadings.label.repel = TRUE) +
  theme_minimal()+
  labs(x= "Principal Component 1", y = "Principal Component 2", title = "Fast Food Nutrition")+
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust= 0.5,
                                  face = "bold",
                                  size = 16,
                                  margin=margin(0,0,10,0)))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(10,0,0,0))) +
  theme(axis.title.y = element_text (face = "bold",
                                     size = 14,
                                     margin=margin(0,10,0,0)))
food_biplot
## Warning: Removed 371 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

Figure 1: Principal component analysis: fast food nutritional content. Analyis performed on 371 common fast food items. Smaller angles between variables (maroon arrows) indicate highly correlated nutrients, such as carbohydrates and fiber. Variance of the variables are represented by arrow length, with longer lengths representing larger variances.

Summary

  • Carbohydrates and fiber in fast foods are highly positively correlated. Protein, vitamin B12 and vitamin B6 appear to be positively correlated as well.

  • Protein and sugar in fast foods are negatively correlated (as one increases, the other decreases).

  • Many components of fast foods appear to be uncorrelated, including vtiamin E and protein, energy and vitamin B12, fiber and fat, and sugar and vitamin E.
